bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 21, 1875

div1.p: Reed expresses his devotion to Emilie Lawrence. He expects a permanent military assignment in the spring.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 21, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Octr 21st, 75.

div1.p:
The let-
ter which I awaited so pa-
tiently, knowing that it would
surely come, came last eve-
ning- And after perusing it, I
thought that it was well worth
waiting for. Was my visit like
a “bright dream”? Would that I
could add another to your
list of happy visions! If
my prescence can, at any
time, afford you one happy
hour, what would I not do
to ensure this? To know that your
hours have passed more pleas-
antly, & that your cares, for the
moment, have been forgotten,
ah! this it is that makes my
heart to beat light & free!
Your happiness, my own darling
E., is the great aim & object
of my humble existence- Gladly
would I sacrifice all earthly
ambition & pleasures, if by this
means, I could make your life
happy- For myself, for my suc-
cess, I care nothing, save in so
far, as it would contribute
to your joy. And Oh! my darling,
if I can pass through life, with
you, a happy woman, by my
side, I shall be satisfied -- no
matter what the obstacles,
what the barriers, what the
reverses or trials may be!
So that when you tell me
that my coming is like a bright
vision, no sweeter tidings could
fall on my ear! To me, the week
spent, at your dear home,
was the brightest, happiest
reality of my life! I delight to
look back upon it, & in my
mind & memory to trace each
day & live it over again!
And when each pleasant
scene has passed in review,
I put them back into my heart,
each in its place, & think, what-
ever else may happen, these can
never be taken from me!
Nay! not only shall they re-
main, but others, as bright
& pleasant, many, many others
shall be added to them!
If it lies within my power,
not many months will pass
over my head, before I shall
again look into your dar-
ling face. From intelligence
that has reached me, since
my return, I will not be or-
dered away from Willet's Point
till next Spring; and such
being the case, what would,
what could, prevent me from
appearing in the Old North
State, about next February
or March? Remember, my
precious, that this is only rum-
or, & may not be true; and yet
I place considerable confi-
dence in it. I hope, by Nov.
1st to know more definitely,
when I will lose no time
in sending you words-
And, now, my darling, little
Sweetheart, there is a matter
concerning which I desire
to ask your advice- Do
not, please, refuse to lend an
attentive ear, as I know you
will not, & to tell me just what
you think of the matter- Don't
say that you are not entitled
to a hearing, because I consider
that you have a right to know
of all my plans & underta-
kings.

The matters, which I desire to
speak of, is this. My Sister is
very anxious that her little
daughters, & especially her
oldest, Anita, should go to
Murfreesboro, next February, &
she has written me a long,
& sweet letter, asking me
to assume the pecuniary re-
sponsibility of her education,
till such time as she may
graduate; provided I consid-
er myself able to do so. Her
husband, being enrolled in
the category of Methodist Preach-
ers, out of his abundance, is
not able to educate all of his
children, & hence Sis seeks her
brother's assistance. What shall
I do, my darling? Shall I not
respond? Is there a better
deed that I can do, than to
educate my own Sister's
daughter? Could anything speak
more forcibly to my heart than
this request from a darling
sister? Tis true that my
means are limited, yet can
I, can we, not spare a few
hundred dollars towards the
education of this dear child?
I have not answered her letter
yet, but, with your consent,
I will write & take upon
myself the responsibility of
her expenses at Murfreesboro.
Let me know, my precious,
just what you think of the
plan I propose, and do not
hesitate to state your opin-
ion & wishes fully- I shall
gladly listen to anything you
may have to say, & shall feel
that whatever course you
endorse is the right one-
Bless your darling heart, I
never propose to embark
into any undertaking, with-
out first seeking your
advice & approval, which
I value more highly than all
that others may have to say.
Before closing my letter, one
thing I will say befe're it
escapes my memory -- I refer
to my address. Hereafter, my
darling, please direct your
letters, Whitestone Post Of-
fice, Willet's Point, N.Y. Harbor-
Very often the Post Master or
Mail Agent makes the mistake
of sending my letters to Flushing
instead of Whitestone, & hence
my lettersthey are detained two or
three days- Your last, which
I should have received on Mon-
day, did not reach me till Wednes-
day night,- & thus, I was kept two
days & night from its precious
contents.
div1.closer:
Adieu, my darling,
Believe me, as ever,
Your fond & devoted Walter.
